Brown Deer's Keith Peters, once a state Class C championship coach in Alaska, has led the Falcons to their first winning season in almost two decades. He offered two answers to the prediction question:
"Are you asking me who's the favorite or who I think will win? The favorite, by record, should be Stevens Point. But, you know I think the winner might come from the Sheboygan South-Shawano game. Shawano's good, with a great tradition, and South's record is deceiving. They're coming out of a league that probably was at its toughest in years."

Shawano's Norm Davis looks toward Milwaukee and Madison, and warns not to overlook South Milwaukee. "I always lean toward the two big cities with teams like North and La Follette," Davis said. "They're usually talented and scrappy. But, Stevens Point still has to be impressive.

La Follette's Pete Olson, whose Big

Eight Conference player of the year, Rick Olson, is averaging 28 points a game, agrees, in part, with Davis.
"In recent years, Milwaukee-area teams have been very good," Olson said. "Stevens Point's numbers are im pressive, but all we're thinking about is North If we shoot well, we could win it all."
"Stevens Point!" says South Mil waukee's Don Karnowski, with em phasis. The Rocket coach, however admitted his choice is easy because his Milwaukee Suburban Conference eam plays the Panthers first. "They have the record and the top ranking We have a tough team and its success didn't surprise me, but we're concerned with Point."
Currie, however, is looking to the winner of the La Follette-North game.
"We're ready after beating ourselves in several games this year. If we can get by La Follette . . Well, that's the game for us," he said

Tradition has proven that few favored teams emerge as champions. Manitowoc fell two years ago, and La Crosse Central's once-beaten Raiders didn't live up to expectations in 1979. Last year, Milwaukee Madison, with five losses and a dark horse role, won it all before relinquishing the title later because of a player-eligibility

La Follette wouldn't trade its deadly shooting Olson for anyone at the line. The $6-1$ senior guard is an 86 percent free-throw shooter. He and he Lancers will be the sentimental avorites in Madison after pulling out pair of stunning last-second regional and sectional victories over Stoughton and Madison West.
"There are some dandies down here," said Lancer Coach Olson. That's what makes it a state tournament."
So it all begins today - without a favorite, but with a lot of king-sized hopes.
